In any case, phoenix-tracing-webapp has long been merged, and wouldn't expect anyone to pick this PR up.

Closing, as this has a follow-up PR.

Closing.

@virajjasani  All the tests passed in the last 2 commits and the checkstyle comments are not relevant.
Can you please review?

Most of this doesn't even look relevant to memory usage.
I seem to have mixed up some branches.

Please check the test failures.

We've discussed the upper/lowercase escaping offline.
Could you check what results Oracle returns in that case, and try to approximate its behaviour ?

@virajjasani can you also add some unit tests in `WhereOptimizerTest` . Those tests verify that the scan range is generated correctly. I want to make sure that we have some tests for descending columns with like expressions.

1. I've checked oracle 23c version, strangely, it seems that it has the same faulty behavior, so the `columnLabel` and the `columnName` are the same in `ResultSetMetaData`. On the other hand, jdbc docs states:

> getColumnLabel: Gets the designated column's suggested title for use in printouts and displays. The suggested title is usually specified by the SQL AS clause. If a SQL AS is not specified, the value returned from getColumnLabel will be the same as the value returned by the getColumnName method.


2. We discussed offline the upper/lowercase escaping problem, and come to the conclusion to not include `"` in the returned String to have the same behavior as before.

3. Test failures were caused by using cfamily wildcards ( `SELECT cf.*`), where the previous implementation returned the column name for both `getColumnLabel` and `getColumnName` (without `cf.`). With this change, `getColumnLabel` returns just the column name as before, but `getColumnName` returns the column family as well (see `QueryCompilerTest.java`). @stoty What do you think,  what would be the correct behavior in this case?

> 1. I've checked oracle 23c version, strangely, it seems that it has the same faulty behavior, so the `columnLabel` and the `columnName` are the same in `ResultSetMetaData`. On the other hand, jdbc docs states:
> 
> > getColumnLabel: Gets the designated column's suggested title for use in printouts and displays. The suggested title is usually specified by the SQL AS clause. If a SQL AS is not specified, the value returned from getColumnLabel will be the same as the value returned by the getColumnName method.
> 
> 2. We discussed offline the upper/lowercase escaping problem, and come to the conclusion to not include `"` in the returned String to have the same behavior as before.
> 3. Test failures were caused by using cfamily wildcards ( `SELECT cf.*`), where the previous implementation returned the column name for both `getColumnLabel` and `getColumnName` (without `cf.`). With this change, `getColumnLabel` returns just the column name as before, but `getColumnName` returns the column family as well (see `QueryCompilerTest.java`). @stoty What do you think,  what would be the correct behavior in this case?

I think that the patch's behaviour is fine, and follows the standard as much as possible.
We couldn't find the reason for removing the CF from the Label, but as this is the previous behaviour, and there is a comment in the code that confirms that this was the intended behaviour, we have left it as is.

Reading the JDCB javadoc, it says that isCaseSensitive refers to the column, not to the column name.
This is extremely underspecified, but in my interpretation, this means that the current implementation is incorrect.
Since Phoenix distinguish between case-sensitive and case-insensitve strings, I think that we should simply return "true" here.

We could just easily return false, as for comparison Phoenix uses standard case insensitive collation rules.

On second thought, I think that it's better to handle the isCaseSensitive issue in a separate JIRA.
Looks like there are some BackwardCompatibilityIT failures.
